bestBHT.bht: Having found a ship, Paul set forth, sailing over to Phoenicia. The details provided in this account are so vivid that one would almost think it was taken from a journal. Paul started with a small vessel that anchored each night at different ports, but upon reaching Patara, he seized the opportunity to board a larger merchant ship that could sail across the open sea. These circumstances favored Paul as he made his way towards Phoenicia, a stop on his journey to Jerusalem.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Their former one going no farther, probably."
One would almost think this extracted from a journal of the voyage, so graphic are its details.
Albert Barnes: Unto Phenicia - See the notes on Acts 11:19. Phoenicia was on their way to Jerusalem.
Marvin Vincent: Set forth [ανηχθημεν] . Or set sail. See on Luke 8:22; Luke 5:3.
Archibald T. Robertson: Having found a ship (ευροντες πλοιον). Paul had used a small coasting vessel (probably hired) that anchored each night at Cos, Rhodes, Patara."
But at Patara Paul caught a large vessel (a merchantman) that could sail across the open sea."
Crossing over unto Phoenicia (διαπερων εις Φοινικην). Neuter singular accusative (agreeing with πλοιον) present active participle of διαπεραω, old verb to go between (δια) and so across to Tyre.
John Gill: And finding a ship sailing over unto Phoenicia... we went aboard."
Lighting on another ship, which was bound for Phoenicia... we went aboard.
And set forth; on the voyage.

bhtAttempts.bht: Having found a ship, Paul and his companions set forth, sailing over to Phoenicia. It seems as though this account may have been retrieved from a journal, as the details are so vividly portrayed. Paul initially used a small vessel that anchored each night at various ports, but upon arriving in Patara, he seized the opportunity to board a larger merchant ship that could sail across the open sea. The circumstances were in Paul's favor, as they made their way towards Phoenicia, a stop on their journey to Jerusalem.

Having found a ship, Paul set forth, sailing over to Phoenicia. The details provided in this account are so vivid that one would almost think it was taken from a journal. Paul started with a small vessel that anchored each night at different ports, but upon reaching Patara, he seized the opportunity to board a larger merchant ship that could sail across the open sea. These circumstances favored Paul as he made his way towards Phoenicia, a stop on his journey to Jerusalem.

Paul found a ship and set forth, sailing over to Phoenicia. The details in this account are so vivid, one might think it was taken from a journal. Initially using a small vessel that anchored each night at different ports, Paul switched to a larger merchant ship at Patara that could sail across the open sea. These circumstances favored Paul as he made his way towards Phoenicia, a stop on his journey to Jerusalem.
